name: Post-Traumatic Heterotopic Ossification
chief_complaint: I can't move my elbow anymore, and it's getting harder every day. There's a hard lump that wasn't there before my accident.
physical_findings: Restricted passive and active ROM in affected joint
treatment: Focused physical therapy to maintain ROM
Surgical excision if causing significant impairment
prognosis: Variable - early intervention can prevent progression but established HO often requires surgical management with risk of recurrence. Most cases stabilize within 6-12 months post-trauma.
description: Pathological bone formation in soft tissues following trauma, burns, or neurological injury. Typically develops 1-4 months post-injury, with ectopic bone forming in muscles and connective tissue around joints. Most common in elbows, hips, and shoulders following severe trauma or immobilization.
